lecture_item.title: Social Computing Middle and High School Curriculum
lecture_item.taught_when: Given at Seattle middle and high schools
lecture_item.description: We created different learning and activity modules that revolve around different subtopics within social computing, including data management, online behavior, encryption, misinformation, machine learning and bias, and HCI careers. These materials were designed specifically for middle school and high school students. We have deployed these materials in local middle school and high school classrooms and after-school clubs in the greater Seattle area and have also used them in training materials for K12 educators.

lecture_item.title: Building technology for society (and all of its complications and messy consequences): case study on automated content moderation
lecture_item.taught_when: Gave to UW CSE 143: Programming with Data Structures (Autumn 2020)
lecture_item.description: A deep dive into automated content moderation and the considerations around and consequences of deploying automated content moderation tools when it comes to users, communities, platforms, and society. The content is tailored to first or second year undergraduates in Computer Science to consider the ethical and societal implications of technologies such as automated content moderation and social computing system design. Many pointers to current events surrounding this topic.
